texts.text: It's bright out there.
I was writing, and...
Right. I've got a group of four—two men, two women—and the fairy.
I already know I want to end on a big wedding scene, but it still doesn't feel like enough.
Say, why don't I throw in a group of completely unrelated actors for good measure?
They can get caught up in the fairy's mischief too.
Then they can be the entertainment for the wedding, which gives me an excuse to bring the cast together.
That way, everything will feel neatly tied up by the time the curtains close.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Uh... Oh?
My forehead hurts.
How long have I been passed out atop my desk?
I suppose the fatigue had to catch up to me at some point.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Ah!
I jump out of my chair and grab the script.
Did I fall asleep while thinking of ideas? Have I not written a single word?!
My eyes run over the letters on the parchment in a frantic hurry.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: *Sigh* Thank God...
Thankfully, everything I came up with is actually written down here.
I somehow managed to make all the additions before passing out.
After stretching my aching limbs, I gather the papers together.
But then, I hear a sound coming from the ground floor.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Dad?
Going downstairs to the pub, I find my dad peeling potatoes in his usual spot at the counter.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Oh, good morning.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Ah, you're up. Morning, Son. Sorry about yesterday.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Are you sure you should be up?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: I'm fine. Ed came by this morning. He brought soup and all.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Really? That's good to hear.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Were you out last night?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: ...Yeah, for a bit.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: I see.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I think I may need to go out for a bit again tonight, while it's just the regulars here and there's not much business going on.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: We never get much business, so feel free to go out whenever.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Uh, that kind of stings.
Rob and Ed show up as soon as we open up shop for the night.
They must be worried about my dad.
Both are immediately relieved to see him sitting in his usual spot.
I look out the window to see the sun sinking below the horizon.
Olivia said to bring her the script before midnight.
If it's only Rob and Ed here, I can leave the pub to them for a while and run out to deliver the revised script.
There's still time to spare.
The mood is relaxed as I chat amicably with them.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: You managed to hand in the script?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah, I got the rest of the money. The client wasn't Spencer, but a woman he was with.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Yeah, right. That pretty lass with the strong attitude.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I was ordered to fix the script, so I ended up passing out at my desk last night.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: All right! Time to celebrate my recovery! A toast to good friends!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: No way.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: I can't allow that. You've already caused me more than enough anxiety.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: But my boys, ale is the best medicine!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: More like the source of a thousand ailments.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Truer words have never been spoken! Don't push your luck now, Boss.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Ngh...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Oh, welcome.
The front door opens, and a group of customers comes in.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Uh, wh-what's this?

texts.name: Customers
texts.text: Hello, folk! You have space for us? We have eight people here.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Eight? I-I'm afraid we...

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: What're you saying, lad?! It'll be a bit of a squeeze, but come right in!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: That's right, you fool! Get that bread!

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: I know it might not be the most polite thing to say, but this is truly a rarity. Let me make some space for you all.
Ed says, addressing the group of men.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: You can say that again. Are all the other pubs in Tenbridge closed or something?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Ah, shut up, you idiots. Come now, budge up next to me.
Rob and Ed pull their seats in closer to my father to make space.

texts.name: Customers
texts.text: Ah, there's space? Thank you kindly.
The men troop in one after the other.
They settle in their seats then place their orders.
Rob was right.
Did all the pubs in town close today or something?
I try to hide my frustration as I continue serving them from behind the bar.
By the time the big group leaves, it's already past midnight.
I can tell without looking at a clock. In this business, you soon develop an internal time tracker.
We sold a lot tonight.
I'm honestly overjoyed at that.
But I wonder why it had to be today of all days.
My fatigue weighs down heavier as I silently clean up the leftover plates and cups.
Now that it's just the four of us, the pub is quiet once again.
It's too late now.
Am I gonna get hounded by that noble with the weird manner of speech, or will I just get thrown straight into prison before getting killed off or whatever?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Hey, Lad. What's wrong? You're not drinking? It's not every day that Ed treats you.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Ah, uh, right. I'll drink.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: We're finally back to the usual calm, so let's get back to our seats and relax for a bit.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Ah, welcome...
A new customer comes in.
He's tall and slender and is wearing a baggy hat.
He's... an unusual sight to say the least.
Usually we cycle through the same few regular patrons here, but I can't remember seeing this person before.
The new customer takes a seat at the end of the bar.
I serve him some of the mashed potatoes I prepared beforehand.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What'll it be? Ale?
The silent customer points to a bottle behind the counter.
There's a bottle of aqua vitae sitting on the shelf behind me.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You wanna drink that? It's pretty strong. And expensive too.
The customer slams his hand down onto the counter.
Then he raises it slowly, leaving behind enough money to eclipse a usual day's worth of sales.
I'll buy the bottle.
A frown streaking my face, I take the bottle, put it in front of him, and serve a glassful.
After gazing at the tawny liquid swirling in his cup for a moment, he points at me.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What, you want me to drink?
He slowly nods.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Oooh! You got guts, lad! You wanna give Will a run for his money, eh?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: That sounds fun. That boy of mine is no lightweight. He got that from me.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: But we cannot guarantee he'll be a friendly drunk. Sadly, he got that from his dad as well.
Heh...
The guy raises his cup.
I take another cup and pour myself some liquor.
I raise my cup. We clink them together and drink up.
The thick liquid burns a hot trail as it goes down my throat.
A bitter and slightly sweet aftertaste remains in my mouth.
Hah...
He blows out a quiet breath then sets his cup back on the counter, signaling for more.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Heh, this is getting interesting.
I serve us both another round of drinks.
And just like the first, we down them in one go.
Again, the fiery liquid leaves a hot trail on its way to my stomach.
The guy puts his cup back on the counter immediately.
I notice a smug grin touching his lips.
Those thin lips seem slightly familiar, for some reason.
I try to follow the thread of thought, but the drinks are already fogging my mind.
And the lack of sleep can't be helping me any.
I pour us another round.
And the cups empty as fast as the first time.
I feel the third drink settle in my stomach.
The heat starts to creep up from my belly, and I can feel it in my cheeks now.
From the glimpse of the man's face that I can see under the hat, he's having no difficulties handling the alcohol.
I don't have a good feeling about this.
I'm not stupid. I am under no illusions that I can win here.
But I can't pull out now.
He tips his cup forward.
There's still liquor left in the bottle.
Our customers usually do nothing but drink cheap ale and slurp down the insipid mashed potatoes I make.
It's rare to say the least that anyone asks for spirits.
I serve the next round.
This time I choke a little on the first gulp and leave some liquid in the cup.
I go for a second swig and take care of the leftovers.
But by the time I look down, the other man's cup is already set for more.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What the heck's up with you?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Oi, Will. You throwing in the towel already?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Remind me again who ruined my sleep schedule with a rush job.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Shall I tag in for you, Son?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What kind of father sticks his neck in a kid's fight?

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Friends, we should all calm down a little.
The guy takes the bottle himself and serves for the two of us.
Driven by indignation, I grab the fifth cup and force it down my throat.
I feel the liquor running over my tongue like a hot, numbing fire.
It takes me several swigs, but it does down.
My throat is burning up.
And the sweet aftertaste is like a cloud of unpleasant fumes.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I think...

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Whoa?!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: ...I'm done for...

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Told you so...
If I was in peak condition, five cups wouldn't even rattle me...
I want to say this out loud, but my consciousness is fading faster than I can open my mouth. My eyelids and tongue feel like lead.
When I wake up, only my dad and the mystery customer are left in the pub.
It looks like I was out a while.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Huh?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Hm? You awake?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: That was a sorry display. Don't pick a fight if you're gonna lose.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'm just under the weather today, sheesh.
I wobble up, still reeling from the drinks.
I have the mother of all headaches.
The back of my throat feels dry and scorched.
The customer is still in the same seat, drinking ale now.
I slowly stand up and move around to the other side of the counter.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Hey, you can hold your drinks pretty well.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You really showed me. Satisfied now?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It's been a pleasure and all, but it's time to close, and I can't serve you in this state. Could I ask you to leave?
You're a courageous one indeed to start your first day by breaking a deadline.
You're off to a bad start, slave.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Mm?
The voice is a little different, but it sounds like...
I fearfully peer under the hat...
And see a gleaming pair of rose-colored eyes glaring out at me.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Have you already forgotten how I ordered you to address me?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: L-Lady Olivia...

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: That will suffice, I suppose.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Lady Olivia?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: So, would you care to inform me why you ignored your master's direct orders in favor of doing... whatever this is?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Ahahahah! When did you become someone's slave, boy?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: This is no laughing matter.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Yes. You were about to lose your neck over thievery charges. It is, indeed, no laughing matter.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Thievery? Hey, is that true, Son?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah...

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Did I really raise such a fool? Why would you do such a thing?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: We can talk about that later.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: What?!
I turn back to Olivia.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Sorry. No, actually. Would you hear me out?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Have you already forgotten your oath from yesterday?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Huh? Is that a woman's voice?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Yes. I never said I was a man, did I?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Oh my. I suppose you didn't.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What are you going around dressed like that for?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: It's convenient, you see.
She says, taking off her hat and letting loose her long locks of hair.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: So, any last words? No lingering regrets?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I know I messed up. I fixed the script, I just couldn't get out of the pub until—

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Show me.
Olivia presents her hand to me.
I sigh and reach for the rolled up script from under the counter.
She snatches it from me and begins flipping through the pages at a fast pace.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I did what you asked. I was up all night writing...
She completely ignores my explanation.
Olivia seems more interested in devouring the script with her eyes.
It looks like I'll have to wait for her to finish reading.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Good. You improved it.
She murmurs, standing up.
Then, she begins reading out parts of the script aloud.
The scene where a woman exclaims her love for a person she hated up until she was slipped a love potion by the trickster fairy.
Olivia recites the man's lines with perfect dramatic cadence.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Whoa, what a nice voice.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Mm, it's a good line, but the rhythm is a bit off. Hey, can we change the wording so—

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Wait.
Olivia shoots me a suspicious look.
That outfit she's wearing intrigued me.
But after hearing that adept vocalization, I'm now certain.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Dad.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Yeah?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I have something I need to talk to this customer about, and it's a little personal.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Huh?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Can you leave things here to me?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Oh, well. It's not like you're giving me any ale anyway.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Of course I'm not.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: All right, then. You two be nice to each other now.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Thank you. Have a good night.
My father takes his cane and goes up the stairs.
Olivia stares after him for a moment.
When he's gone, the only people left in the pub are me and Olivia.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You...

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: How many times do I have to repeat myself? Call me—

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You're thinking of performing on stage?!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: ...Whatever do you mean?
I heave an internal sigh of relief.
I suppose even these out of touch nobles have a lick of common sense.
It's prohibited for women to appear on stage like male actors do.
Committing such a sin in front of a crowd of spectators would be akin to slicing your own neck with a sword. The crown wouldn't react kindly to such an offense either.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Never mind, I just thought that—

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Of course I am.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: What do you think I made you my slave for?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You're here to write the best plays for me, obviously.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Wait a moment! You...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You're a woman!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: So what?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You can't act on stage! What batty troupe leader would approve this?!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: That would be me.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Dios mio santo!
Now I'm talking like that madman Spencer.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Is there a problem?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: How would there NOT be?!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Well, you're going to stand on that very same stage.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Excuse me?!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: No, wait. Wait a second.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Am I having a bad dream right now?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'm actually still knocked out from the liquor, right? That must be it.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I have to be. There is no way a woman could be the leader of an acting troupe in Tenbridge.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I wasn't just imagining things when I thought you were off.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Well now, that's one tall wall of delusions you're building there.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Specially when you didn't notice a thing until I told you.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Are those precious jade eyes for decoration alone?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: ...A pub is no place for a woman to come on her own. I didn't imagine one ever would.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Neither is the stage a place for a woman to be, right?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I see your tiny brain is still struggling to follow, so let me put it in a way a five year old would understand.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Ugh...

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Allow me to enlighten you. Right now, your life is in the palm of my hands.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Whether you live or die is my prerogative. The preconceptions in your mind are now mine, and I am what molds and guides your thoughts.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You will forget those stupid preconceptions that tell you that women cannot be in pubs or perform on stages.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Because those foolish ideas do not exist in me. You will cast those discriminating ideas from your mind, this very instant.
After this monologue, she stands up.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I have the script now. Rehearsals will begin tomorrow.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I will not tolerate absences. Next time you won't get away with just an earful.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Are you saying you'll kill me?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I think a pampered boy like you would perhaps prefer death.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You damn—

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I am your master and troupe leader. Choose your words wisely.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: ...I promised to write plays. I'll write as many as I need.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'll write masterpieces that you couldn't even think of if you banged your head against a desk for the rest of your life.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You can't possibly do that as you are right now.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Reading your revisions today made me certain. It's out of your reach at the moment.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: And why would that be?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You're going only from what's in your head, aren't you? It's the same for your dialogues and movements. You've never stood on a stage, and it shows.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Your use of sound is particularly lacking. The story flow is good, but I couldn't point to any line in it as something that could go down in history.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: And I doubt it'll change until you stand upon the stage and recite lines with the audience's eyes upon you.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: The hearts of the audience are more distant than you could ever imagine, but also more sensitive. If the rhythm is bad, no one will be able to relate to you.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: And that's supposed to be a playwright's job?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Undoubtedly so. That is one idea of mine that you have to make yours.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Appearing on stage is a bit much. I'm not an actor.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: And why in the world would I ever go on stage with a woman? I have enough threats of execution without you trying to get me killed by the crown on top of it.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Hmm, so you...
A steady, quiet fire lights up in her eyes.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You're an incompetent oaf who can't do anything but write.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Let me ask you this: Is your calling to stand behind that little counter? Is that what you're living for?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: ...I need to run this pub.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You can call me an ignorant or pampered boy all you want, but I have to be my father's eyes.
She narrows her eyes at me.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What meaning will my life have if I have to abandon my dad and our pub for it?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Hah, you crack me up.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You're just sidestepping the problem. You're even blaming your father for your inability to find a meaning to your life.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: No! I'm not...!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I see even poets lose their eloquence when you hit them where it hurts.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I fixed the script like you asked, but acting on stage is a whole different matter.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Go ahead and kill me if that's what you're gonna do.
I take a deep breath.
Olivia looks up at me, seeming remarkably unruffled.
The silence continues for a while.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Who would I even kill?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You're not even living your own life.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Why should you fear death as you are right now?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You're like a little baby who's never stood on his own two feet.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Why, those eyes have never seen anything for themselves.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: How could I kill what isn't even alive? It's like you're dead already.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Fear of death won't move you. I mean, you already died yesterday. The person standing here right now is my slave.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: ...I need to look after the pub. I can't just close it down.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You're nothing if not a source of excuses.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Run your mouth all you want. You would never know how hard it is to earn your keep every single day without knowing if you'll eat tomorrow.
Olivia slowly picks up her hat.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Rehearsal starts at noon in the Globe.
She says, donning the hat just like before.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Tardiness won't be forgiven a second time.
She leaves, obviously uninterested in whether I'm okay with the time frame or not.
I take a deep breath and sigh.
Then I raise my fist and slam it down on the counter with all my might.
I'm extremely annoyed.
He has not an inkling of the awareness one needs to be a professional.
Why was such talent bestowed upon such an idiotic, naive boy?
If I was blessed with such literary talent, I would be creating masterpieces daily.
I am so deeply annoyed.
I'm sure he doesn't even realize he's acting like a child.
Well then. I'll crush down all of his flimsy excuses.
So he wants time. Fine, I'll give it to him.
I did it all before becoming a noble.
Customer service, scrubbing floors, cooking, you name it.
I can do it all twice as fast and better than him.
I certainly wouldn't have gotten caught stealing deer like he did.
And I speak from experience.
He's too green, in every sense of the word.
I don't have time to dismantle each of his silly little walls one by one.
The selection to see who will perform for the court is at hand.
Olivia's carefree tone still rings in my head.
I don't have the script at hand, but the lines are still fresh in my mind.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Damn it all.
I pick up my quill.
She was right. I know which lines would be hard to enunciate in a real-life setting.
Everything she said was right.
Everything...
Her voice worms its way into my brain.
I'll internalize her delivery and rewrite the rough lines into something that'll resonate in the most beautiful way with her voice.
The course of true love never did run smooth
...Love blinds us sometimes.
No, the rhythm is all wrong.
Maybe like this.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Love looks not with the eyes, but with the mind...
Yes, this is it. This embodies the play's very essence.
She calls me slave, comes in front of my family and friends to humiliate me, and does nothing but deride me with her every word.
My head is full of her voice.
My quill glides over the parchment like never before.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Damn woman...
Clenching my teeth as what I hope looks like a wolfish smile spreads across my face, I let the quill dance across the parchment with a mind of its own.
Between lazy yawns, I trudge through morning prep work at the pub.
I ended up spending all night touching up the lines for every character.
As I reach for the next potato to peel, the front door opens.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Good morning.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You again? By the Lord's bones...

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You've no intention of coming to the rehearsal, do you?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I told you yesterday. I'm not some noble who can afford to waste his time on hobbies.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I can't play around with you.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: The pub opens at night, right?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: And I need to prepare everything before that.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I'll help you.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What?
Are my ears functioning?
No, surely she didn't say what I thought she said.
I'm imagining things.
But as I struggle with my obviously failing senses, Olivia comes stomping up to the counter.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: H-Hey, knock it off.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You're working with your nails in here, huh? I'm surprised you can make any kind of food with this lack of equipment.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Ugh.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Oh, I see. You just mash potatoes and serve them like that.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Does no one complain about this? I find it a little unbelievable.
Olivia rummages around behind the counter for a bit.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I've got the hang of how you handle things around here. Do you have a price list or something handy? A menu of the insipid grub you give customers?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: No, uh, we don't.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: How can you be THIS incompetent?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Ah, shut up! I'm the only one manning the counter, so it's all in my head!
Olivia walks back out into the room and opens up the bag she brought with her on one of the tables.
She takes a piece of paper from it.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Just write down whatever you have a set price for here. I have it in good confidence that you are at least capable of writing.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: N-No, wait!
Olivia stops and looks at me.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'm sorry, but my father and I have always run this pub together. We've never let anyone else work here.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: And we don't even have the money to hire any help. We have a hard enough time feeding ourselves as it is.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Are you trying to mock me? How could I ever accept money from the likes of you?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: And didn't you say this pub is important to you? Are you trying to get it shut down? No one but the regulars will put up with this sub-par service.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: If you could stop running your mouth, it'd be—

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: It'll be bad for me if you can't focus on theater.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: That's why I came to help you. Very much despite myself, I'll have you know.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You...

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: What?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Are you just really bored?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I'm going to impale you.
Just then, my father comes down the stairs.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Hm? I recognize that voice...

texts.name: Father
texts.text: The customer from yesterday is gracing us today as well?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: No, uh, I'll have them leave right away.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Too bad for you, because I'm not leaving.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Shut up!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Ahahahah!
My dad laughs out loud as he makes his way to his usual seat at the end of the bar.
Olivia watches him closely.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Boss...

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Hm? I'm more of a decoration than a boss these days.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: But you are the owner of the pub.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Are you eating properly?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I didn't notice yesterday, but seeing someone this sickly at the bar will only make the awful meals look worse.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: And they already look barely edible to begin with.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: You been running your mouth again, Will?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I didn't say a thing.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: All it takes is one look at that emaciated face. Your skin and lips are all dry; it's obvious you're not even drinking enough water.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: You can take that complaint to my son here. He doesn't let me drink.
Olivia snaps back to me.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Why not?! Are you torturing him? Do you want to kill this man? Aren't there better ways to go about it?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: He's talking about ale.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Liquor isn't water. It'll only dehydrate you more.
Olivia turns back to my dad and almost slaps him across the face with her words.
Ed said the same thing.
Literally everyone does.
It's about time Dad realizes that him and alcohol just aren't meant to be.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I'll make you some porridge. Do you have any milk?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: We don't really buy stuff that spoils that fast.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You're the absolute definition of incompetence.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: That's uncalled for!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I'll go buy some. There'd better be some hot water waiting for me when I get back.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: H-Hey!
With that, she stomps out of the pub without another word.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: You found yourself an odd friend there, eh?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: She's not my friend.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Oh, is that so? So your master, then. She did call you her slave.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Not you too...
My dad has a laughing fit, which soon morphs into a coughing fit.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Eat up.
Olivia serves two bowls of milky porridge in front of us.
She even puts the spoon in Dad's hand.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: So it's not like you lost your sight completely.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Yeah. I still have a little left—I can just about make out what's in front of me. Thanks, lass.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I'm not some lass, my name is Olivia. Do you want to get killed too, old man?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Ahahah!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: What are you laughing at? I see discourtesy runs in the blood with you two.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Sorry, didn't mean to ruffle any feathers. Olivia, yes?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Can you eat it? You really need to. I went through the trouble of making it, so you better eat it all.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Yes, yes.
Smiling from ear to ear, Dad enthusiastically brings a spoonful of porridge to his mouth.
I stare at the scene in disbelief.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: What are you gawking at?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Uh, nothing.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Hurry up and eat or we'll be late for rehearsal.
I do as she says and take my own bite of the fresh, steaming porridge.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Mmh...

texts.name: Father
texts.text: This is good.
It has a warm, mellow texture, and the sweetness spreads throughout my mouth.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: *Giggle*♪

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It's really good. I'm amazed you could actually make something tasty in that kitchen.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Don't lump me in with the likes of you.
This is surprising, to say the least.
Nobles always leave things like this to others. I had them pegged for the kind of people that can't do anything on their own.
I spoon down more of the hot porridge, enjoying the sweet goodness warming my stomach.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Those potatoes...
Olivia is looking down at the pile of potatoes stacked beside the bar.
I chase her gaze to the potatoes then turn back to her.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I usually turn them into mashed potatoes.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I see. So that's what happens when an incompetent man can't cook to save his life.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Did mashed potatoes kill your parents or something?
Olivia turns to my dad.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Boss, I actually want to borrow your son for a while.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Though I suppose he is already my property.
Olivia's tone is disgruntled.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You're gonna give people the wrong impression.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Hm? I thought he was incompetent? What d'you want him for?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Hey...

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: He is incompetent when he's here.
Olivia glances at me.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: But that's not the case in a troupe. He won't be incompetent there.
Dad raises his face in her direction, still taking spoons of porridge to his mouth.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Our troupe needs the plays he writes.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: That's why I'll come help here so he has time for the theater. That's okay by you, right?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Wait, hold that horse. I enjoy working in the pub.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I promised to write scripts for you. I can do that while also doing my job here.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Don't you remember what we talked about yesterday? You need firsthand experience on stage.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You won't be able to demonstrate your true talent until you experience a performance with real actors and a live audience. You can write better than you do now.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Well...

texts.name: Father
texts.text: This doesn't seem like something that's up for me to decide.
My dad faces forward as he speaks, still eating his breakfast.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: That's not the problem, Dad. This pub is... you know...
This is a gathering place for Catholics.
My dad wants to protect the freedom of religion.
I can't say that in front of Olivia, though.
Not with a queen who executes Catholics on the throne.
And Olivia is one of the nobles serving under her.
If we let her hang around in here, we could all end up hanging from the gallows.
Does Dad understand the danger we're in?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Um, I don't think we should let just anyone work here.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: That's about the pub. You can decide what to do with yourself. You're already a man who can make his own choices.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Whatever you decide, no one here will fault you for it. Do you understand?
Dad looks straight at me.
He's probably talking about the people who gather upstairs.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I'll help with the preparations, but I'd like you to open later. In exchange, I'll work behind the bar to help keep sales up.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Huh?! You want to serve people too?!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Rehearsal lasts well into the night. You can't open in the evening, so there's no other choice but to increase the number of patrons.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I... guess?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: It sounds like she has a plan, and a good one at that. We're always told this place needs a feminine touch. And you cook a lot better than Will ever could.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Are you sure we don't need to think about this a bit more?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Just like you said, I don't think we should let just anyone work here. But I think this lass will be fine for the job.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I'm not some lass. The name's Olivia.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: But you only just met her!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: There are things one can see in a clearer light when you have your eyes closed. Remember that well, Will.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Thank you very much. That was good, Olivia. Make me some more tomorrow.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Of course, my food is nothing short of heavenly.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: I got something to look forward to, then.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: So, it looks like we've reached an agreement.
Olivia turns back to me.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Now you have no reason to decline, do you?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Today's rehearsal starts at noon. I shared the script with the actors yesterday.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: We set off as soon as we're done prepping here. Hey, what are you doing? Get a move on, this is your bloody pub!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: ...Is this really okay?
Things are moving too fast for me.
It feels like I'm getting yanked around on a leash.
I trot alongside Olivia as we make our way through the busy streets.
She's fresh as a daisy despite the exertion.
While I feel like a pile of manure.
We arrive, and Olivia goes straight backstage. When she comes back, the whole troupe is with her.
There's another girl among them.
How in the world is this troupe allowed to perform?
Are they all desperate enough to work under a female troupe leader?
I suppose two women isn't much worse than a single one. It only takes one to get you executed anyway.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Everyone, we'll begin rehearsing a new act today. And we have a new member.
Olivia says, then turns to me.
All the eyes of the troupe are on me now.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: His name is William Shakespeare. Our new playwright. We'll be rehearsing one of this scripts today.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: And he'll be acting too.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I divided up the scripts already, so I'll be giving one to each of you.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Um...
Olivia turns back to me, and so does everyone else.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: What?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I made some more revisions last night.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Really? To which character's parts?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: All of them.
Her eyes widen in surprise, and then she scowls at me.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: And why didn't you open your bloody mouth about this earlier? Please tell me you at least brought the revised script.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: No, but I remember all of it.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: All of it?! You remember all the new dialogue?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah, let me see everyone's scripts. I'll fix them up.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I don't know the tone of anyone's voice but yours, though, so I might end up revising the others' lines again.
I make amendments to each script on the spot.
Olivia zealously goes over the new lines as I write them.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I think this improves things. We haven't learned the lines yet, so let's go with the revised version.
She raises her face from the last page and looks at me.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: It's magnificent. Thank you.
Her eyes glitter with an innocent, girlish energy. It's a complete change from her usual high and mighty attitude.
Then, she hands me a script.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: This is your role. Fix it up for yourself.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Huh? Sure.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What?!
I can't help but voice my surprise upon reading the script.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: What's wrong?
The lines here are the ones for a character named Hermia.
She's the target of the affections of two men in the play.
I wrote her as a young lady.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'm playing Hermia?!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Yes?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: That's a woman's role!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Hm?
Olivia looks at me quizzically.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: What about it?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Why am I playing a woman?!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You have a high-pitched voice, your face is pretty enough, and you don't have that much body hair.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You fit this role the best.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: How about you do it?!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I can't play a woman, despite what you may think.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Why?! You were pretty much born for it!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: If I play a female part, I'll be found out. I'm too pretty.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Didn't you say yourself that women shouldn't be on stage? Therefore it's only natural for men to play the female parts.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: W-Wait, what? What about that girl?!

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: Me? I'm a guy, though? I have dangly bits and all.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Uh, d-dangly? As in, between your legs?! Why?!

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: Why? Because I'm a guy, silly.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: A guy! A bloke! But how?! You're so cute and adorable and pretty!

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: Eheheh.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: He is quite the looker, isn't he? His name's Kiki, a fellow slave of yours.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: A fellow slave?

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: A pleasure!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah, uh, my pleasure... Wait! Why am I playing a woman again?!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Okay, everyone, take some time to read through your lines. You can take your scripts with you.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Commit all your lines to memory before the day ends. We will strike back on the last day of the Admiral's Men's performance.
Despite my protests, the rehearsal gets under way.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Admiral's Men...

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: They're our rivals.
Kiki whispers into my ear, which sends shivers up and down my spine.

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: To be rivals, I'd think you need to have a semblance of equal footing.
A particularly lanky member of the troupe talks into my ear from the opposite side to Kiki.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: So... which troupe is the losing one?

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: Ah, don't make me spell it out.
He and Kiki begin giggling among themselves.

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: Ah, where are my manners? The name's Thomas. Which happens to be this one's real name, actually.
Thomas says, pointing at Kiki.

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: Eheheh!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: So you're both Thomas.

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: I was told to crossdress and change my name because it was getting annoying to have two people with the same name. That's why I'm Kiki now. The chief probably forgot my real name by now.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: That's tyranny! And you're okay with it?!

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: You get used to it.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: By the bones of...
Ah, just forget it.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: So, is the difference that big between this troupe and the Admiral's Men?

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: There's a world of difference.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: The distance between the clouds and the ground can be easily closed.
Olivia snaps back.
Kiki and Thomas go silent in the blink of an eye.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: With Will's writing, that is.

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: Whoa, she's really talking you up.
The two of them begin poking fun at me with wide grins on their faces.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Are you done chitchatting? Let's begin.
Olivia begins to read the narration out loud for everyone while pacing back and forth.
I look down at my script and follow along.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: This won't work at all.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: This is so ghastly that words fail me. It's just no good.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You don't need to tell me, I know it's bad.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: How can you be embarrassed in front of our troupe members?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: When this place is packed with the audience, you'll need to project your voice loud enough for them to hear you on the third floor.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'm aware, it's just that...
For a moment I thought there was something off with my script.
But that illusion was quickly dispelled.
The level of the troupe members here is so low it's obvious even to an amateur like me.
And I'm far worse than even the lowest of them.
I realized as soon as I tried.
Why am I even here? This whole acting thing is Greek to me.
A little spot of regret starts to sprout inside my chest like an insidious vine.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You're too stiff, and you seem to know absolutely nothing about women.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You don't need to tell me that...

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Didn't you write this?
I give a weak nod.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: It's so strange. You write women so well.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: So why can't you express it on stage?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: How about we go to a brothel so you can get rid of that virginity?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Hey!
Her eyes widen in surprise.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: See? You can raise your voice!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Is this normal practice for an acting troupe?! I hardly think all this criticism is constructive! We're not gonna get anywhere at this rate.

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: I can't speak for other troupes, but this is how things usually are with us.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: How do you not know? Does no one know how the competition operates?

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: The ones good enough for that go to other troupes, obviously.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Is this a troupe of rejects?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Insult us as much as you like, but we're working with what we have. Moaning and complaining won't change a thing.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I'm used to being being looked down upon.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: If you want to talk behind my back and blame me, feel free. I care not for what you say behind the scenes.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: But when I'm here, you all are...

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: ...my slaves. Do not forget that.
The air in the theater freezes over.
Is it really possible for them to excite an audience like this?
I see nothing but low spirits and slumped shoulders among the other troupe members.
Everything Olivia points out is sound, which only makes being here more unbearable.
For the most part, I simply wait for it to be time to leave.
And I feel like I'm not the only one taking this approach.
I simply pray that Olivia doesn't feel like focusing on me and wait for the rehearsal to end.
Our unproductive rehearsal drags on until evening.
When Olivia goes backstage, Kiki and Thomas approach me.

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: You're doing well, new guy. Will, was it?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah.

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: She got you by the short hairs too?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Huh?
Too?

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: You wouldn't be here otherwise.

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: Truth is, we used to be jewelers.

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: Of fake jewels, but yes.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You were fraudsters?

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: Put simply.

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: Yeah, that's about right.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: And you got busted.

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: We thought it would be a good idea to scam that Spencer guy.

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: And he found us out right away. Said they weren't beautiful or whatever.

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: We were about to lose our heads.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: And she asked to keep you two?

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: That's the gist of it.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I see.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Are rehearsals always like this?

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: Yep.

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: Pretty much. It's just the leader going in circles and getting nowhere.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: ...How long have you two been here?

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: About half a year.

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: Yeah, sounds about right.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Maybe it's not my place to say, but why does this troupe even exist?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: There doesn't seem to be a single decent actor among us...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Uh, err, not that I think I'm better than anyone. You two are a world apart from me.

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: Aw, no need to worry. We all know we're terrible.

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: The only reason we're all still here is because Spencer is the patron for this whole thing.

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: Definitely. An actor of a theater troupe without a patron is as good as a vagrant.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: That sounds a little extreme.
When I say that, the two of them stop in their tracks.
They exchange a silent glance then look back at me as if I said the weirdest thing in the world.

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: Will, you really know nothing about the theater, do you?

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: But you write such good stuff. You've really never worked for another troupe?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: No, I...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I usually run a pub. I've never been part of a troupe.

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: What?!

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: Really?!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I do like writing, though.

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: We won't think less of you, promise.

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: You should leave right now and find a decent troupe to work for.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: But from what you say, I don't think I'm gonna have much luck elsewhere if my stuff isn't good enough to make it here.

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: No, it's the other way around!

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: Your writing's too good for this crummy band of nobodies. You stand out like a sore thumb.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Oh.
Now I understand where they're going with this.
It seems like there isn't a single person in this troupe who cares about putting on a good play.
...Except for the leader, that is.
They probably just want to do the bare minimum in a situation they were forced into.
Just trying to keep a low profile and not call attention to themselves as they put up with being called slaves.
Is that the way to play it when it comes to this troupe?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Will.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: There's still time before you have to open the pub, right? We're taking a detour. Follow me.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Wait, where are we going?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: The Lily Theater.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What?
Isn't that where Ed works?

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: That's the base of the Admiral's Men.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: They're performing 'The Jew of Malta' today.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Doesn't sound like it'll be very popular with a title like that.

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: Don't be silly!

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: Ever since it came out, Jewish characters have been popping up left and right in plays all over the city.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: The author is Christopher Marlowe.
Huh?
I feel like I've heard the name before.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Right now, he's the number one playwright in all of Tenbridge.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: He's the person you must surpass.
Yes, Ed mentioned that man.
The playwright who has become the best in Tenbridge with his violent, bloody stories.

texts.name: Kiki
texts.text: The bloke's a genius!

texts.name: Thomas
texts.text: Now I'd like to see someone write something better than Marlowe.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Silence, slaves.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Have anything to say?

texts.name: Kiki&Thomas
texts.text: Yes, Ma'am.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: But you just told them to be quiet...

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Let's go.
'The Jew of Malta' by Christopher Marlowe, performed by the Admiral's Men, consisted of five acts in total.
I could only describe the play as shocking and violent in nature.
The cheers of the audience poured in, and at the end, the playwright himself appeared on stage.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Do all playwrights come out to greet the audience like that at the end?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Only when the cheer merits it.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: When a play touches the hearts of an audience, they won't calm down until they see the playwright.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Everyone loves a good poet.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I see...
Deafening applause and cheers still fill the surrounding area as we exit the theater.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Right now, the Admiral's Men are definitely the number one troupe in Tenbridge. Both in terms of popularity and talent.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Why so pensive?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Uh...
The audience's reaction was staggering indeed.
And the acting was incredible.
However...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I found the story rather... obtuse.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: How so?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It's a revenge tragedy that doesn't shy away from depicting death, right? Its political backdrop and undertones are rather marked as well, so I somehow feel...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: If the play truly touched the audience's hearts, they couldn't possibly have reacted with such unbridled excitement, right?
That's an interesting opinion.
A voice from behind surprises me, and I spin on my heels.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Ah...
It's the man who came up onto the stage after the play.
It's...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Christopher Marlowe...

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: Do you make a point of going around calling people by their full name?
The corners of Marlowe's mouth curl up into a fish-and-chips-eating grin before he lets out a petulant chuckle.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: You saw my play, didn't you? It wasn't to your liking?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Uh, I...

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: How about the beauty that accompanies you?
Olivia gives him a nonplussed smile.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: Normally, I pay no attention to the comments of each and every audience member. They're worthless, and I hardly have the time.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: But your words intrigue me ever so slightly.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: Care to expand on your thoughts?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: No, uh, I was just talking out of my...
When I try to turn away from Marlowe, Olivia grips my sleeve.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Don't run away.
Olivia whispers low enough for only me to hear.
She's staring straight into my eyes.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Is that an order?
She gives a swift nod.
I sigh in resignation and face Marlowe again.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I thought it was a really stunning play. I think it's amazing how it could rouse people in such a way.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: You propose that's because the audience was blind?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I didn't say that...

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: Don't beat around the bush. You write too, don't you?

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: Your sleeves are covered in ink.
I raise my hand out of reflex and notice black stains on the sleeve.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: I'd like to hear the thoughts of a fellow writer. What is it that my plays lack in your eyes?
It's then that I realize...
A crowd is slowly forming around us.
Of course.
We're right in front of the Lily Theater.
This is his territory.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: Hear, hear, all!
Suddenly, Marlowe spreads his arms wide in an exaggerated gesture and addresses the crowd around us.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: This man here is a fellow playwright!

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: And it seems like today's play wasn't quite good enough for his discerning tastes!

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: I am asking for his reasoning to sustain this opinion right now. For future reference, of course.
He says, smirking at me all the while.
Olivia stands behind me, silent.
When I look back, I see her gaze is set firmly upon me.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Speak your mind.
Olivia whispers behind me.
Why is she doing that?
I don't know her very well, but she's obviously not one to cower behind someone else if she has something to say.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Is that another order?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: A suggestion, actually.
I sigh again, turn to Marlowe, and take a deep breath.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I wouldn't say the play wasn't good. I just got the impression there was something inconsistent about it.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It felt like different people wrote the first and second halves—

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: Interesting.
Marlowe rudely cuts me off.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: So this means you see the people who cheered for tonight's play as a bunch of blind fools for enjoying what you call an inconsistent play.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Don't put words in my mouth. The audience has no blame in this.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'm not pointing fingers at anyone.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I know how easy it is to get swept up by emotion in a group.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It's just that...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: When people get swept up by sensationalist elements and the essence of the piece doesn't touch anyone's heart...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I think it's a pity, that's all.
Marlowe blinks at me in silence.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: Did you hear that, everyone?
Abruptly, he turns to the audience.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: This greenhorn playwright says that he pities each and every single person who saw us off with applause today.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Hey! I didn't—
I try to speak up and stop Marlowe's bad faith rousing, but Olivia pulls me back.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: I would have your name.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: You have the obligation to give your name after directing such hostility at so many fair people.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Wouldn't you like that...
He poisoned the well, and he's the one holding the reins of this conversation.
I can hear some people hollering already.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I am...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: William Shakespeare. I'm the playwright for the Spencer troupe from the Globe Theater.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: Globe Theater? Oh, I see now.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: That troupe of amateurs, is it?
Laughter rises from around us.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah. Compared to you... to the Admiral's Men, they're a bunch of stale potatoes. I realize that.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I don't think we can beat the quality of your actors, at least.
Marlowe raises an eyebrow sharply.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: Just the actors?
I nod in response.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: So you presume your scripts are better?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I'd say so.
Sneers and shouts ring from around us.
I hear a lot of aggressive jeering.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: You are quite interesting, William Shakespeare.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: Shall we put it to the test?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Huh?

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: Who shall be chosen to perform for the Royal Court?

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: There is no better way to decide who is better. You would not dare call the nobles of the court blind.
What is this guy going on about?
The court led by Queen Elizabeth is made up of the blindest people in the land.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I don't care about the nobles of the Royal Court.
Olivia stomps down on my foot.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Ouch! What's your problem?!

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: Break your quill and cast it into the gutter, Shakespeare.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Huh?!

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: England has no need of playwrights who desire not the honor of being selected to perform for the Royal Court.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: Smooth talkers who would deride poets with a love for the written word have no right to hold a quill in their hands.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: The clothes are supposed to make the man, but so far all you well-dressed nobles have turned out to be rats!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Can you stop manipulating every single damn thing in your favor?!

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: That's why I propose a fair contest. Let Queen Elizabeth, she who loves theater more than anyone else in this country, decide who is best.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: You mean to say that you feel it is an insufficient stage to play out this feud?
I'm sick of this.
And the worst part is that I know there's no way out.
The moment I gave my name, it was over.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: ...All right.
The corners of Marlowe's lips curl up in a smirk.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: The Admiral's Men and the Spencer troupe will fight for the nomination to perform for the Royal Court. The loser will put down the quill. For life.

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: I, Christopher Marlowe, playwright of The Admiral's Men, hereby swear to honor this agreement.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I, William Shakespeare, playwright of the Spencer Troupe, swear as well. Is that good enough?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: All I gotta do is write a better script than you, right?

texts.name: Marlowe
texts.text: I'd say we've had enough fruitless arguing for one day. Let our words clash on the stage, as fellow bards.
Marlowe swiftly leaves the scene.
The spectators that had gathered around scatter quickly as well.
I'm already exhausted.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Olivia.
She looks up at me.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: What is this Royal Court performance?
Olivia stops and stares at me.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You are aware the queen enjoys theater, yes?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah.
We left the Lily Theater and went straight to open the pub.
As usual, no one was waiting for us to open.
It's just me, Dad, and Olivia at the counter.
For the first time, I thank the stars there's no one else around.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: She holds regular theater parties at the Royal Court that she participates in. They perform outdoors during summers, and mostly indoors during winter.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: There is no greater honor for a troupe in Tenbridge than being selected to perform for the Queen's pleasure.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I see. So, who decides who gets the honor?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I believe she has appointed people to go watch plays regularly and make recommendations to her.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: It's often the case that a play that has become the talk of the town ends up being selected by the Queen.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: She really likes theater, huh?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: It has been quite a while since the Queen chose a troupe.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: As things stand, it'll surely be a play written by that Marlowe man.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: That'd only make sense.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Would it now? You do remember you swore to stop writing if that were to happen, yes?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah, and I obviously don't care for the man! But the truth is the truth!
She looks at me as if I said the stupidest thing ever.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: And why did you spur me on?! This happened because of you!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: What do you mean? Money couldn't buy this kind of publicity. I'm certain all who heard that little spat will be there to watch our performance.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Really?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: No matter how excellent a script, or how well you act it out, it's all for naught if no one cares to watch you perform.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I suppose there's no point arguing about it now. I could keep writing scripts under another pen name, I suppose.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: No.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: But that guy probably doesn't write all his scripts himself, I think. That means there must be ways to write anonymously.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Banish those lowly standards from your mind. You are on a whole different level than Marlowe.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: And if your name garners attention, it'll help our chances of getting selected.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Then how about you put your name on the line too?! This is your fight!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Does everything I say go in one ear and out the other? The audience there watching you argue wasn't small. If they heard my voice, it would lead to the worst possible ending for both of us.
People would recognize her on stage as a woman. Right.
I see now.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Besides, a spat between bards will get people talking.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You're pretty brave, you know. I admire you, truly I do.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I'm an actress. We must be resilient.
Actress...
Did she come up with the word?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: And if we're elected to perform for the court, I...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Mm?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Huh? Eh? Did we walk into the wrong pub?

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: My...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Oh, welcome.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Is that Rob and Ed I hear? Took you two long enough.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: And who might this be?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Huh? Isn't that the lady who was with Spencer?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It's a long story. Come on in.
Rob and Ed exchange looks before joining us at the bar.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: So, that's the story. We'll have to open the pub a little later from now on. I'm sorry if it's an inconvenience for you guys.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: My lad, forget about that!

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: This cooking is quite delicious.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Yes! That's the important news!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Naturally. I hope you came ready to pay.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Olivia, surely you don't intend to treat all our customers with that attitude, do you?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Is there a problem with it?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Of course there is!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Our customers seem quite happy with it, though?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Yeah, the little lady's easy on the eyes too.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Who are you calling little lady, Rob? Do you want to leave here alive?

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Yes, I can see a passionate following forming here now.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You're one of the peddlers that visits the Spencer Manor, right?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Ah, you remember me?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: So you found this playwright by drinking here, huh?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Indeed I did, thank you.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: So you are officially working with a troupe now, Will?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: It's nice to see the apple falling far from the tree for once!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: What's that supposed to mean?! Knock him out, Will!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah, yeah, let's not start this again.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Olivia, please deliver justice!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Ouch!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Why did you hit him?! He's a customer!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I was expressly told to hit this man.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: For all that's holy! You can't just hit people out of nowhere like that!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: They're not your slaves!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Ahahahah! But you are her slave, ain't that right?

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Slave?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Uh, is that some kind of kinky thing between you two?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Please, let's not go there.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I saved his life and now it belongs to me, as my slave.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: He tried to steal one of Spencer's deer and almost got his head cut off for his trouble.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: What?! Lad, what the bloody hell were you thinking?!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I don't think I was, sadly... As embarrassing as it is to admit, I had a major lapse in judgement.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Was it that night?
I nod.
Ed simply shakes his head.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: I told you not to worry about the money.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: But I didn't steal anything, in the end.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Just as Spencer was about to have my head cut off, Olivia bought me.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: That's why he's my slave.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: You are paying for your mistakes, my son.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yeah...

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Olivia, would you please hit him across the noggin for me?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: With pleasure, my good man.
For the love of... Whatever.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: No matter how hungry you are, you never take what is not yours. You get it now?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I do, better than ever. I will never try to steal again in my life.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Well, let's not get all sour now. We were all young once. Didn't you have your fair share of mistakes too, Boss?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Can't say I ever stole from anyone, no.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: And in the end, Will didn't either, did he?! Can't move on if you start pointing fingers all over again.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: You're writing plays for this lovely lady because you're atoning for your mistakes, right?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I... suppose I am, yeah.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You could use a little more backbone, I'd say.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: You should work hard to make up for your past misdeeds. It'll be good for your soul.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I know, thanks.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: You can start by working hard for the court performance.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: As in the Royal Court? Our Will?!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: That's what we're aiming for. Although, if he can't even do that, I doubt he has much chance of atoning for those mistakes.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Hahah, you got yourself into a right mess, eh?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It sure looks that way. The whole court thing started today, actually.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: So you will be competing with the Admiral's Men from the Lily Theater, then.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: The Admiral's Men? You mean against Marlowe?!

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Battle lines were drawn just a few hours ago. Whoever loses has to stop writing.

texts.name: Rob&Ed
texts.text: Whaaat?!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: How reckless can you get?! You only just became a bonafide playwright, lad!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: It's not like I was looking for a fight, you know?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: If you're gonna compete, might as well make it flashy and attract an audience. It's exactly what we need.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Or so she says.
Rob and Ed exchange another glance.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: You've found a very, uh, eccentric master, huh?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: More like completely off her rocker.
After that, two first-time customers show up, and Olivia serves them.
Her haughty attitude turns out to be a huge hit among the men, so our sales for the day are double the usual.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: So...

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Huh?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I don't think I'm cut out for this bartender thing.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Eh?!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: You only just realized?!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: That's news to nobody but you, ahahah!

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Gotta say, the food's delicious today.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Olivia made that too.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: She's a member of the nobility, right?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Sure looks that way.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: She's rather strange, isn't she?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Aren't all nobles a bunch of oddballs?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: In all my years, I've never seen a noble doing kitchen work.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: The way she talks is new to me too.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Perhaps there's more to her than meets the eye.
I watch Olivia talk to a customer sitting near the entrance.

texts.name: Father
texts.text: I feel more at ease with that lass around.
Rob and Ed nod at my father's words.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: ...I've really been outdone, huh.
Late into the night, the new customers leave with a full bellies and red faces.
The only ones left are Rob and Ed.
I take sips of ale while washing the dishes.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: So, you're gonna compete with that Marlowe guy? You got some kinda plan or something?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Nope.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Even if you two were to both put out scripts of the same quality, I wager the audience would still pick Marlowe's over yours.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: His name carries weight, and he's popular already.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Write something overwhelmingly better than anything that joke of a man can produce. That's the plan.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I don't think that's much of a plan.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: But we can't do much else, can we?

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Indeed.
Marlowe is the most popular playwright in Tenbridge.
On the other hand, I only started for real yesterday.
Is this even a competition?

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: It'll be fine, Will.
I turn to Ed.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: As I said before, I've always believed that your writing has nothing to envy Marlowe's.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Ed, was it? You like theater?

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: I work at the Lily Theater, so I watch the plays of the Admiral's Men daily.
Olivia nods, looking rather impressed.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: When will the Royal Court selection take place?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Two months, at the earliest.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: So if you push it a little, you could put out three plays in that time.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Yes.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Will may be the one writing, but you have Rob to back you up, and I can always give advice if you need it. You're not in this fight alone.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: You will succeed.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Thanks, Ed.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: He's damn right! I'll go load up on as many rumors as I can.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: The problem now is your acting prowess, or the lack of it.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Huh? You're acting too?!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Huh, what role?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: The main character. A female role.

texts.name: Rob
texts.text: Ahahahah!

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Fits him like a glove! Come on, show us what you can do!

texts.name: Will
texts.text: No, thanks.

texts.name: Ed
texts.text: Well, it's not like actual women can play the female roles, so they usually go to handsome men like Will.
I steal a glance at Olivia.
She's nodding at Ed's words with a pleasant smile on her face.
She really is an actress, huh?

texts.name: Father
texts.text: Oh, what I'd give to see my son crossdressing with my own two eyes.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Ah, shut up!
After Rob and Ed leave and my dad goes back upstairs, Olivia and I are left cleaning the pub.
It was my first time working together with someone since I started manning the counter, and it really made things a lot easier than being alone.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Thanks for the help.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Huh?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I just...

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: I don't need your gratitude. All you have to do is let me read the best scripts the world has ever seen.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I knew you'd say something like that.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Then why are you bothering me?

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Good question...

texts.name: Will
texts.text: I think I needed to thank you, despite everything.
Olivia stops scrubbing the table and stares at me.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Must be the bard in you talking.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Well then, see you tomorrow.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: You'll come tomorrow as well?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: How impossibly foolish can you get? Just helping you for a day wouldn't solve a thing, would it?

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Unlike you, half-hearted isn't in my vocabulary.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: Bye.
Olivia walks to the door.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Olivia.
She looks back at me.
Her white hair fans out and sways as she goes.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: ...Thanks.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: How many times must I—

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Yes, all I need to do is write, I know.

texts.name: Will
texts.text: Still, thanks.
She leaves without saying another word.
I smile, despite myself.
It feels like a storm is brewing in my chest.
What is this feeling?
I'm just doing what I need to fulfill my purpose, my ambition.
But...
That place feels comfortable and warm.
I feel like I understand why he's trying so desperately to protect that little house.
All the members of the troupe are mere tools to me.
Not a single one of them is motivated to do more than they need to.
That's why I treat them as such. Tools to further my goals.
Words of gratitude like his...
How many years has it been since anyone has spoken such words to me?
I want to go back tomorrow as well.
It's cramped, the water is cold, and the ingredient selection is paltry at best.
But it trumps Spencer's manor.
*Sigh* I don't need these silly thoughts. Not now.
The more I enjoy my time there, the harder it becomes to go back to the estate.

texts.name: Olivia
texts.text: A little too late, isn't it?
I take another sluggish step on my way back to that huge, hollow mansion.
